address.streetAddress: 111 Queen's Park Bloor St and Avenue Road

description: Discover one of the world's most universal and dynamic art forms. Explore the Gardiner Museum's internationally-renowned collections of pottery from the Ancient Americas, Europe, China, and Japan, as well as contemporary ceramics. Visit the Museum's special exhibitions, sign up for a clay class, take part in weekly family art activities, dine at Clay Restaurant, and find the perfect gift at the Gardiner Shop.

reviews.title: Fascinating pottery
text: We were planning to visit the ROM, but there was a long lineup of people planning to take advantage of the free admission, so we crossed the road and visited the Gardiner Museum instead. The exhibition of works by Magdalene Odundo is particularly interesting, but the selection of new additions is also very good.

reviews.title: Exit Through The Gift Shop
text: The Plato to NATO of ceramics and porcelain. The gift shop has a great selection of contemporary Canadian ceramic art. I got a $3 discount for travelling to the museum with Presto, so keep that in mind.

reviews.title: The Intrigue and Secrets Stolen Around Porcelain
text: I had no idea that the arcana for making porcelain was so valuable that spies were involved in getting the formulas. I also had no idea that people sunk money in porcelain as a way to show off their wealth. I learned a great deal at this lovely small museum.

reviews.title: A Worthwhile Foray Into Ceramic Art At the Gardiner
text: Last week,I returned to the Gardiner Museum which has an outstanding collection of European Porcelain Creations. I relished its fine array of 18th Century Meissen Porcelain Creations many of them modelled by Johan Kaendler such as;"Monkey Orchestra","Pair of Pug Dogs"(from Royal Palace of Warsaw).I also appreciated "Young Sultan and Sultana Dressed For Masquerade Ball(Hochst),"Cat and Mouse(produced in St. Cloud,France produced in the 18th Century)and "Bottle Vase With Scarab Beetle in Japanese Style(Minton ),and "Andromeda".,among others.

I also saw its tip top collection of Majolica  Creations such as "Dish With 2 Lovers",Deruta),"Dish From Story of Tyreus and Polynice,1522",Francisco X. Avelli's"Jug With Anthromorphic Beast",and "Scene With Christ and Doubting Thomas",among others..Most of the works on display were produced by Italian Artisans in the 16th Century Italian Cities such as;Deruta,Faenz,and Urbino.

At this Ceramic Museum,I also liked the Modern Creations of Jun Kaneko("Hizen Dish With Landscape,Japan"),Jean Pierre LaRocque("Horse With Baggage"),and Shary Boyle("Cracked Wheat").There was a plethora  information,so that you could understand these splendid ceramic and porcelain creations better.I enjoyed my foray into the study of Ceramic Art.

reviews.title: A must see along with the ROM and AGO!
text: Easily one of the top three museums in Toronto. Don't let its size delude you. It's packed with tons of amazing artifacts. Would definitely recommend everyone to visit, especially with a free pass on Wednesday or via TPL Maps.

reviews.title: If you like ceramics, visit the Gardiner Museum
text: We really enjoyed this small museum whose focus is ceramics. There are over 5000 items from around the world on display from a variety of time periods. If you like clay, ceramics, pottery or porcelain, you will enjoy this small museum.  Their cafe, CLAY, is lovey.

reviews.title: Great collection
text: Well laid out and a lot of interesting pieces within the collection. It‚Äôs worth checking out if you‚Äôre into ceramics. I went during a week day and it was not busy at all. There‚Äôs a restaurant on the upper level.

reviews.title: 'Housewarming' is a fascinating small exhibition
text: Having lunched in Clay, with some time to go before our concert in Koerner Hall, we visited the Housewarming exhibition, which consists of a number of constructions by Karine Giboulo. She found her immediate inspiration in Canada's experience during Covid, and she has done an excellent job marking the event and its consequences. Well worth a visit, which can be augmented by going through the permanent collection.

reviews.title: Blown away experience
text: I went to visit the museum on a Monday afternoon to see Karine Giboulo‚Äôs Housewarming. I was intrigued by all those miniatures. Was welcoming at reception by friendly Alejandra who gave me an extra discount for having the Presto card as well as the seniors rate.

Was asked for my receipt upon entering the exhibition hall as told at reception. Madeline and Sarah were the attendants and let me know about the do and don‚Äôt in a very professional manner. I was very impressed by the exhibition and spent 90 minutes taking photos and videos. It‚Äôs also free entry on Wednesday evenings. More details on the Housewarming exhibition on their website. Across the street is the Kent Monkman exhibition which is next on my list.

reviews.title: Housewarming special exhibit weak
text: As they say "each to their own" but we did not find the Housewarming special exhibit that compelling.  The museum has had much better special exhibits over the years.  The other small special exhibit - Replicas and Reunions, was interesting and well presented.

reviews.title: Absolutely terrible customer service! i regretted recommending this place to my friends
text: It was a nightmare dealing with the Gardiner museum receptionist! Very bad customer service and absolutely inflexible in accommodating our requests. When politely asked to pick up our pottery stuff the receptionist just gets really upset and so worked up and even called the security on us trying to chase us out! We recommended the ceramic class to our friends and it's unbelievable how they treated us this way. You might as well just go to AGO.

reviews.title: Ceramics
text: I visited this museum alone. It is truly awe inspiring, the artistry, the design the complexity of some of the items on display. Toronto is very lucky to have this museum. Well worth a visit.

reviews.title: Don‚Äôt miss the Ai Wei Wei exhibit
text: Always a treat to visit this museum.
The 3rd floor usually has contemporary interesting exhibit, last year Yoko Ono and now Ai WeiWei. Closing soon....

reviews.title: Stories Behind the Ceramics
text: Not just a museum of ceramics. This wonderful museum not only shows an exceptional ceramics collection, but brings to life the stories behind pieces. Contemporary work and traditional.

reviews.title: Trip to The Gardiner Museum
text: Outstanding selection of Mayan, Chinese, European and English ceramics. History panels contributed to the history and development of earthenware and porcelain wares. Beautifully displayed with a nice presentation of modern Canadian artists.

reviews.title: Pleasantly Surprised
text: Visited for the first time to see the Ai Weiewei exhibit which was fantastic.  Even saw the artist himself who was at a reception.  Also enjoyed the permanent exhibits.

reviews.title: Ai Weiwei and Much More!
text: Wonderful museum with incredible exhibits of porcelain and ceramics ranging from the Ancient Americas and Chinese dynasties to the present day Ai Weiwei Unbroken installation. We would visit again on a guided tour to learn more about the history of the work.

reviews.title: Excellent collection from ancient to modern- manageable size
text: An easy walk from hotels, or from subway, this is a nice sized museum with periodic special exhibits. Well curated and presented. I am not a fan of porcelain, but enjoyed the collection that were older and more modern. An overlooked gem! ....also has an interesting looking resto.

reviews.title: Ai Weiwei
text: The Gardiner has a fine permanent collection of ceramics from many different places and times. It also has a good restaurant with a great view. Yesterday we were here for the Ai Weiwei exhibition. It is an eclectic collection of pieces that gives good insight into the range of his work. Highly recommended!

reviews.title: Ai Wei Wei surprises
text: Just saw the Ai Wei Wei exhibit at the Gardiner and found it stimulating and emotional.  As a conceptual artist he has the idea and then has the professionals execute it, thus he creates an interesting combination of modern esthetics with traditional techniques.   The rest of the Gardiner consists of excellent examples of ceramics from around the world.  There is also a nice gift shop and and hands-on area.

reviews.title: Small but worth visiting
text: I went to the Gardiner Museum not sure about what to expect. I read lots of ceramic pieces where display there, and I thought, a museum that only displays ceramics?
Well, it's a very nice place with hundreds of ceramic pieces. The collections were beautiful. My favourites were Modern & Contemporary, Ancient Americas and Japanese Porcelain.
The Museum is in a great location. Just one block away from the subway. Admission is super affordable. They even have one day with free admission from 4 to 9 p.m.
I spent one hour and a half there and when I left I was happy. I recommend this place to anyone.

reviews.title: Beautiful museum, right across from the Royal Ontario Museum
text: My first visit of this beautiful space.
The collection is delightful, with so much history.
Interesting artifacts, nice gift shop.
Worth a visit!

reviews.title: Gem of a museum
text: The Gardiner is a small museum but has a wonderful collection of ceramics. Don't miss stopping here.The Diana Reitberger Collection of contemporary ceramics was especially pleasing to view.

reviews.title: Small, beautiful space, excellent exhibits
text: This is a small, beautiful space--including a lovely rock garden at the entrance and a balcony on the third floor, with interesting views of Bloor and the surrounding area. The permanent collection is an excellent overview of ceramics and pottery, including some items from the indigenous Americas. There are daily tours (which I missed), check their site for details.

Right now the  "Savour: Food, Culture in the Age of Enlightenment" is on and it's lovely: recipes, knitted veg, good consideration of trans-Atlantic slave trade and food in Europe, plus, all the nifty ceramics!

In the lobby, there is a small exhibit, "Cannupa Hanska Luger: Every One & Kali Spitzer: Sister" that commemorates the crisis surrounding murdered and missing Indigenous women, girls, trans, and queer community members continues, with thousands of documented cases in both Canada and the U.S. Powerful.
Both exhibits are on until January 2020. Definitely worth the visit if you're in Toronto.

reviews.title: Lovely ceramics good for 2-3 hours of museum fun
text: right across from the Royal Ontario Museum, the Gardiner has a very impressive collection of ceramics. Well organized with very informative displays, We thoroughly enjoyed this museum. Also has a lovely gift shoppe!

reviews.title: wasting of time and money
text: This is a small musuem with very unworthy collections. Do not be fooled by the smart looking web photos. its a gallery maybe, definitely not a museum.Beautiful front garden, and time wasting to go inside.Japanese name Hizen is WRONG on every piece, its Bizen.

reviews.title: One of the nice museum in Toronto
text: Despite the small size, clean and friendly environment. Easy to navigate for the floors. Designed in four levels. Just visited two levels. Ground level is for Ancient Americans, Italian Renaissance Maiolica, English Delftware, Modern and contemporary Ceramics. The second floor is Japanese Porcelain and Its Influence, Chinese Porcelain, European and English Porcelain.
The Gardiner shop is on first floor but still is expensive.
We used Map ticket which we got from Public library so our tour was free.

reviews.title: Small but good
text: Good collection of old and modern ceramics, nice history on ceramics as well, very pleasant visit, glad I went with  my teenage daughter (even she thought it was cool)

reviews.title: Ceramics Museum
text: It is a ceramics collection from around the world that is mainly predictible. However there are a couple of displays with Japanese ceramics that are more contemporary and interesting. It is an intimate, quiet space.

reviews.title: Exceptional Tiny Perfect Museum
text: Set back from the street, quiet in it's refined facade, this is a museum often passed over and missed. It's well worth a visit. It takes us on a truncated and general tour of ceramics which is interesting, and shows some exceptional examples.

For a couple of hours of stimulating respite from the city, this is a perfect choice. **There is a terrific restaurant for a light bright fresh lunch on the upper floor with grand views over the street and the ROM at good prices. It's light-filled space with a vaulted ceiling is relaxing and one of the best off-the-beaten path dining rooms you'll find. Enjoy!!

reviews.title: A pleasant hour or two
text: Even if you have only a casual interest in ceramics, you'll be able to while away an hour or so at this specialty museum. That it was free admission the day we visited made it even more enjoyable!

reviews.title: Excellent museum!
text: A world-class museum of ceramic arts. Everything is gorgeous and amazing. The collection is curated with great love and care. The large posters that describe the main sections of each gallery are very well written. They give you lots of interesting information without going into irrelevant details.

reviews.title: Small. Focused. Well worth it.
text: This is a museum devoted to ceramics though the ages. This is not a specific interest of mine, but the collection is presented so well, I couldn't help but engage. I learned many interesting things and won't look at dishes the same way going forward. The museum does an excellent job of showing you artifacts, pointing out that artifact in a painting where it is being used, and explaining how it fit into the history of that period.  Ceramics and pottery aren't everyone's thing, but if you like art and museums this is definitely worth the time.

reviews.title: Interesting and amazing things to see!!
text: First time visiting this museum, I totally was impressed. I loved the Porcelain area, amazingly beautiful!!! It is remarkable how a couple out of their love for certain things, and giving to their community, have created such a beautiful place to explore and learn. Moreover,

the staff is friendly, polite and attentive. If you love the clay, ceramics, pottery in general, you will find a lot of exhibits in the museum! At the lower level young artists creating their pieces of art, as well. A day of knowledge and fun at the same time!! Must visit again!!!

reviews.title: Interesting for those who love arts and ceramics
text: An adult ticket costs $15. The museum has collections from the 10th century until now, from Europe, America and even Asia. The exquisite collects include a pig tureen and ladle üêñ, a whimsical monkey orchestra üêí, and a full feast in porcelain ü§§. One should come at 2pm anyday to join a guided tour that shares the history and behind story of the collections.
(p.s. The museum also holds clay classes, which you shouldn't join. They are overpriced and received really poor reviews from both TripAdvisor and Facebook.)

reviews.title: Pleasant short visit
text: I happened to be nearby and decided to pay a short visit.  There is a small cloak room with a few lockers for backpacks.  The museum was pleasantly uncrowded making for a fine, slightly less than one hour visit.  The pieces are diverse and interesting and the small shop had some lovely pieces to purchase. I bought some small cups and a saucer and the shop keeper did a great job packing them up in bubble wrap for my flight home.

reviews.title: World class Specialty Museum
text: Had a brief, but edifying experience at this wonderful museum because of its unusual and focused exhibits, not found elsewhere. There is porcelain, ceramics and clay from ancient to modern times from many parts of the world, including, Europe, Asia and South American. In addition the special exhibit focal point was dining in earlier century with a replication of a table setting. Their collection best typifies how form and function works perfectly through the shapes, designs, facade and their usefulness in every day life. My short visit provided me with a overview of what this fine Museum has to offer, so I will return soon to be part of a guided tour to further enrich my appreciation and understanding. The staff are personable and professional and the tariff is quite reasonable for all the Gardiner Museum provides to the discerning visitor. Also, don‚Äôt forget to patronize their fine quality restaurant- Clay! Very Highly Recommended!

reviews.title: an breathtaking porcelain collection in the heart of the city
text: 3 floors packed with beautiful old and modern wares from China, Japan, Europe and North America. the collection is arranged geographically and chronologically, but there is a lot of overlapping, as different regions influenced and inspired others. The collection is truly amazing! there is a restaurant (licensed) on the third floor.

reviews.title: Top Class Ladies‚Äô Lunch venue
text: View an art installation (you do have to pay museum entry) then have lunch!   The setting, meal and service are highly polished in the bright second floor modern dining room filled with warm sunlight.   It‚Äôs a setting to lift the soul through art and food.

reviews.title: Don‚Äôt miss Food in the Age of Enlightment
text: Beautifully presented and interesting show. Comparing different countries‚Äô attitude toward food. Tromp√© l‚Äôoeil of many variety, including some amazing knitted food by a Swiss artist. You get a discount with a ROM membership.
